channel.title: Plot on It works
channel.description: Recent content in Plot on It works

item.title: MoMA Style Sad Plot 2.0
item.description: 1) Clean Reproducible Code library(here) library(tidyverse) library(readr) library(dplyr) library(ggthemes) library(extrafont) library(stringr) library(extrafont) moma <- read_csv("http://bit.ly/cs631-moma") moma_NA <- moma %>% drop_na(artist_gender) %>% filter(exchange != TRUE) ggplot(moma_NA, aes(x = year_acquired, fill = gift)) + geom_bar(tat="identity",position ="identity", width = 1) + labs(x = "Year Painting Acquired", y = "Number of Works Acquired") + ggtitle("How MoMA Gets Its Art: Gifts and Purchases Over Time") + scale_fill_manual(name = "Acquisition Type", labels=c("MoMA Purchased", "Gift"), values=c("black","#ff3300")) + coord_cartesian(xlim = c(1928, 2018), ylim = c(0, 80)) + scale_x_continuous(breaks=seq(1930, 2015, 20)) + facet_wrap(~artist_gender) + theme_tufte() + theme(panel.

item.title: Waco Home Prices Sad Plot 2.0
item.description: 1) Clean Reproducible Code knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(tidyverse) library(ggthemes) library(plotly) library(RColorBrewer) waco <- txhousing %>% filter(city == "Waco", year >= 2004) %>% group_by(year) %>% mutate(median_waco = median(median), gt_median = median >= median_waco) waco_homes <- ggplot(waco, aes(x = year, y = median, color = gt_median)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.7) + labs(title = "Waco, TX median Sale Price Over Time", subtitle = "Note, the show Fixer Upper debuted in 2013", caption = "Source: ggplot2 txhousing data") + xlab("Year") + ylab("Median sale price by month") + scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2015, by = 2)) + scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(90000, 175000, by = 10000)) + scale_color_discrete(name="Yearly Median Home Prices", breaks=c("FALSE", "TRUE"), labels=c("Below Median", "Above Median")) waco_homes + theme_minimal() 2) What Type of Graph?

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
